BIG TECH‚ÄôS AI BETS - are we back on (AI) track?

"Big tech companies ‚Äî¬†Alphabet¬†(Google),¬†Amazon,¬†Apple,¬†Meta,¬†Microsoft, and¬†Nvidia¬†‚Äî earned nearly $2T in aggregate revenue in 2024, up 15% from 2023. 

They already dwarf the private tech sector ‚Äî surpassing the¬†combined value of all 1,200+ unicorns¬†by a factor of 3 ‚Äî and after a period of layoffs, they‚Äôre back to hiring, with 2024 headcount growing an average of 7% YoY.

Now, they‚Äôre betting big on AI to power their next growth phase."

They are expected to spend over $320 billion on AI infrastructure in 2025. This is a big jump from $246 billion in 2024.

Here are some key points:
‚û°Ô∏è Massive Investments: Amazon plans to spend $100 billion, followed by Microsoft with $80 billion and Google with $75 billion. Most of this money is going into data centers to support AI growth.
‚û°Ô∏è AI and Cloud: AI is driving cloud services forward. Microsoft Azure grew by 31% last year, and Google Cloud is focusing on security to win more business customers.
‚û°Ô∏è Acquisitions Are Back: After a slowdown, big companies are buying again. Alphabet‚Äôs $33 billion deal for Wiz shows how important AI-focused acquisitions have become. Nvidia is also leading in funding AI startups.
‚û°Ô∏è New Markets: Companies are exploring areas like humanoid robots and general-purpose AI agents that could change industries.

AI is driving big tech's investments and hiring has ramped up again. 

Have we surpassed the AI trough of disillusionment? What do you think?

Most people and businesses operate without the drive of curiosity, innovation, and a growth mindset. 

They remain confined within their daily routines. 

Their established practices create a rigid corporate culture. 

There is a strong resistance to change, akin to a corporate immune system that rejects new ideas.

To be at the forefront of innovation is to anticipate the future consistently.

We all live in our bubble‚Ä¶

text:
No progress without (good) debates. 

We need to debate, including the one about AI. And we need to have different opinions.

On the one hand, there are those who see the potential, the positive benefits and the world-changing effects.

On the other side are those who are worried and have fears and concerns. 

There are always two sides to the same coin. It's what is called the principle of polarity. 

Black and white, yes and no, agree and disagree.

I belong to the group of visionaries, positive thinkers, curious, and sometimes also naive.

But I am less on the technical side and more on the humanistic side of AI. Does that sound counterintuitive? 

Let me explain! To me, AI, if used correctly, will bring two things to lift human potential: 

ùüè. ùêñùêû ùê∞ùê¢ùê•ùê• ùêõùêû ùê¶ùê®ùê´ùêû ùê¢ùêß ùêüùê•ùê®ùê∞
The challenge-skills balance is a key trigger for experiencing flow. It describes the state in which the demands of a task slightly exceed a person's abilities. If the challenge is too great, anxiety can arise, while boredom sets in if the challenge is too low. Flow occurs in an area known as the ‚Äòflow channel‚Äô and lies between these two extremes. This means that through working and living alongside AI, we will experience more flow.¬†Repetitive and mundane tasks can be handed over, and complicated tasks and complex questions can be solved more easily.

ùüê. ùêÜùêûùêßùêÄùêà ùê∞ùê¢ùê•ùê• ùê¶ùêöùê§ùêû ùêÆùê¨ ùêõùêûùê≠ùê≠ùêûùê´ ùê≠ùê°ùê¢ùêßùê§ùêûùê´ùê¨
Now that we have an omnipotent assistant whom we can ask, we must rethink our thinking. We need to become more curious again. It's not about advising AI; it is about asking the right questions and thinking in the correct pattern. We need to ask ourselves:¬†
‚ÄòWhat instructions could I give or what question could I ask so that the AI understands and gets me from A to B, solve a problem, or execute a task?‚Äô
This thinking will be more systemic, problem- and solution-orientated. 

I'm still so excited about what the future will hold for us. 

Steven Kotler recently wrote:¬†Humans, in flow, who can collaborate with each other, and with AI, are going to own the future. 

Agree?

By the way: I have a whitepaper about flow and respective research added to an open Perplexity space for free. DM me if you want access.

reshared_post.text:
In our new paper we ran an experiment at Procter and Gamble with 776 experienced professionals solving real business problems.

We found that individuals randomly assiged to use AI did as well as a team of two without AI. And AI-augmented teams produced more exceptional solutions. The teams using AI were happier as well.

Even more interesting: AI broke down professional silos. R&D people with AI produced more commercial work and commercial people with AI had more technical solutions.

The standard model of "AI as productivity tool" may be too limiting. Today‚Äôs AI can function as a kind of teammate, offering better performance, expertise sharing, and even positive emotional experiences.

This was a massive team effort with work led by Fabrizio Dell'Acqua, Charles Ayoubi, and Karim Lakhani along with Hila Lifshitz, Raffaella Sadun, Lilach M., me and our partners at P&G: Yi Han, Jeff Goldman, Hari Nair and Stewart Taub

I‚Äôve seen many companies get stuck testing AI, but never fully using it.

Pilots are comfortable. They promise innovation without real commitment.

This week, I spoke at the Microsoft AI Tour and shared an important observation:

Companies that scale AI across their whole business grow twice as fast and make three times more money from their investments.

This is what I see what separates them from the rest:

‚û§ They don‚Äôt chase every AI idea. Instead, they pick 2-3 valuable use cases that directly boost profits‚Äîlike automating customer service or predicting product demand‚Äîand commit fully.

‚û§ Instead of counting how many pilots they‚Äôve done, they measure impact, not experiments.

‚û§ They build AI directly into daily operations. AI becomes invisible‚Äîquietly automating tasks and freeing up people‚Äôs time, from warehouse logistics to sales forecasting.

How do you do that, though? Many companies struggle with setting themselves up for success.

What I‚Äôve seen work well is this: The fastest moving companies organize their AI teams around a central ‚Äúhub‚Äù that builds and shares proven solutions, enabling the rest of the company (‚Äúspokes‚Äù) to adopt quickly and easily.

Europe often moves too slowly with new technology. We‚Äôve missed chances before, and we can‚Äôt afford to do that again.

AI is our chance to finally get it right.

It was fun being on stage with my colleague Lara Spendier from Avanade. 

Always inspiring to see the energy and curiosity in Austria‚Äôs AI community!

As Sam Altman put it: Europe needs to play to its strengths.

On Friday, my colleague Nicole B√ºttner, CEO of Merantix Momentum and a founding partner of Merantix Capital, joined Sam Altman on a panel at Technische Universit√§t Berlin. Her message was clear: Europe and Germany have all the right ingredients to capitalise on the AI moment, but we must act fast and decisively.

The fact that OpenAI is setting up an office in Germany in 2025 is both a huge compliment and a wake-up call.

It‚Äôs a compliment because it validates the strength of our talent pool and underscores the business potential in Europe. But let‚Äôs be honest‚Äîthis is also yet another wake-up call. Germany and Europe need to focus on what we do best, rather than trying to compete in the LLM race. That‚Äôs not a game we‚Äôre likely to win. Arguably, no one will, as models become cheaper, commoditized, and open-source - just look at the latest DeepSeek news to see where things are heading.

So what should Europe do? Play to our strengths.

We have a massive opportunity in the next wave of AI if we focus on where real value will be created: applying AI to specialised domains and solving global challenges in our key industries, from manufacturing to healthcare, finance, and logistics.

Europe holds some of the world‚Äôs most valuable proprietary datasets and deep industry expertise. OpenAI has clearly recognized this. As reported by Handelsblatt, their pilot customers in Germany already include Bertelsmann SE & Co. KGaA and Zalando.

But time is running out. We likely have one or two years to ensure the next generation of founders stays and builds here‚Äîotherwise, we risk being left behind in the AI story.

I‚Äôm excited that OpenAI is joining the German AI ecosystem. But the biggest AI businesses of the next decade won‚Äôt be infrastructure companies. They‚Äôll be application-layer companies solving global challenges.

If we don‚Äôt act now, valuable data will leave Europe, and even more value creation will happen elsewhere. Niche solutions won‚Äôt be enough‚Äîwe need globally competitive, superior AI products built here.

Europe has a choice: lead or follow.

My actionable 100-day plan for Germany (easily adaptable across Europe) is here: https://lnkd.in/drYfXgy5

Watch the full panel with Nicole, Sam, Volker Markl and Fatma Deniz, here: https://lnkd.in/dfG9r3-r

Otto ist ein echtes Vorbild in Sachen #Innovation. Und andere deutsche Unternehmen sollten genau hinsehen. Warum? Weil das Ergebnis von KI tats√§chlich mehr "Spa√ü bei der Arbeit" und eine "h√∂here Zufriedenheit" ist. 

Otto Group hat schon 2023 ein eigenes KI-Tool namens ogGPT entwickelt, das auf der ChatGPT-Technologie von OpenAI und dem Azure OpenAI Service von Microsoft basiert.

Das Tool wurde Ende September letzten Jahres f√ºr rund 26.000 Mitarbeitende im DACH-Raum eingef√ºhrt und in der ersten Woche nutzten bereits √ºber 4.200 Mitarbeiter*innen den KI-Assistenten, der auf das komplette Firmenwissen zugreift.

Ein solches System ist der einfachste einstieg in noch viel komplexere und zukunftsf√§higere Ans√§tze, die mit einer einzigen Applikation √ºber das gesamte Unternehmen umsetzbar sind. Ein sch√∂nes Beispiel, wie der Arbeitsplatz der Zukunft aussehen und eine #Transformation gelingen kann.

‚ñ∂Ô∏è Die Verwaltung investiert in KI... sehr gut
‚ñ∂Ô∏è Man versteht, dass es durch den demografischen Wandel bald mehr als nur ein "kleines" Bottleneck gibt... besser sp√§t als nie
‚ñ∂Ô∏è Die Kooperation der Agentur f√ºr Arbeit ist mit einem deutschen KI-Unternehmen... Alternativlos auf lokaler Ebene
‚ñ∂Ô∏è Es gab schon erste PoCs... Vorbildlich, wobei man "Techplattform" mal pr√ºfen m√ºsste... so ein fertiges Frontend, bei dem was ich hier als Features lese, ist es sicher noch nicht...
‚ñ∂Ô∏è Fokus liegt auf repetitiven Aufgaben die die KI √ºbernimmt (Bearbeitung von Antr√§gen oder Bescheiden)... Gut, f√ºr die Arbeitsmoral der restlichen 65%
‚ñ∂Ô∏è Mitarbeiter k√∂nnen ihr Wissen an die KI weiter geben (Pharai Catch)... das ist super, macht alles aber auch komplexer (Fact-checking, etc.)
‚ñ∂Ô∏è Aleph Alpha h√§lt Llama3.1 in der Hinterhand, weil man um die eigenen Schw√§chen der Modelle wei√ü... nun denn
‚ñ∂Ô∏è Auf der Einen Seite sagt man, man m√∂chte kein diskriminierendes Verhalten der US Modelle, gleichzeitig aber hat man genau ein Solches als BackUp... Widerspr√ºchlich 
‚ñ∂Ô∏è Bis zu 19 Mio. in einem 4-Jahres Rahmenvertrag (macht ca. 40 Euro pro User pro Jahr) und da soll Dev, Tech, Training, Data Governance mit drin sein? ... Good Luck... f√ºr jeden Euro AI braucht es 2 Euro f√ºr Change
‚ñ∂Ô∏è Die Kooperation der Schwarz-Gruppe mit Aleph Alpha entsteht hier sicher auch, weil man mit 10% Anteilseigner an AA ist... aber gut, dass man f√ºr Cloud und AI dann zwei deutsche Pioniere nutzt...

Was wirklich wichtig zu verstehen ist: AI ist eine Reise, auf die man sich begibt. Denn die M√∂glichkeiten sind - Stand heute - schon unglaublich vielf√§ltig. Und der demografische Wandel, wie auch der Fachkr√§ftemangel per se, sollten die T√ºr f√ºr AI-Anwendungen weiter √∂ffnen. Das geht aber nur, wenn Unternehmen eine gewisse Vision f√ºr AI haben. Das sollte, auf der einen Seite nicht einzig Business-Case getrieben sein, auf der anderen Seite nicht nur von der AI-Excellence betrachtet werden. Die Integration ist wie das Prinzip von #Innovation zu verstehen. Es geht √ºberhaupt erst einmal darum, ein Mindset zu entwickeln (und ich komme mir schon bl√∂d vor "Mindset" zu schreiben, ist aber so). Eine Offenheit, Neugier, Bereitschaft zu Lernen, Fehlertolleranz, etc. - alles Bestandteile einer solchen Reise. Und ich sage bewusst nicht "Projekt", sondern Reise, die, wenn richtig erdacht und beschritten, n√§mlich "human-centred", die Art und Weise der Arbeit nachhaltig positiv ver√§ndern wird.
Da macht also die Arbeitsagentur, unterm Strich, ganz sch√∂n viel richtig.

Leadership shuffles in AI‚Ä¶

Stability AIs Emad Moustaque steps down as CEO. It follows a turbulent 12 months for the company‚Äôs leadership team which has seen it replace its CTO and lose a VP of product, a VP of engineering, a VP of R&D, a head of research and two large language model leads, according to news from Sifted.

Then, a couple of days ago, there was Inflection AI, making news as its co-founders, Mustafa Suleyman and Kar√©n Simonyan, will join Microsoft AI. Big deal, especially for Microsoft. 

And don‚Äôt forget Sam Altman's quick trip from OpenAI to Microsoft and back again.

It's all part of the big shuffle. 

As everything shifts, I‚Äôm left wondering about the future of AI for businesses and investments‚Ä¶

Is AI at a turning point already?

What‚Äôs the driving force behind? New ideas, ethical guidelines, or just climbing to the top?

What‚Äôs the impact for VCs for future investments?

And at the same time my perception shifts‚Ä¶starting to put things into perspective. It‚Äôs just a game of Thrones - as usual. Nothing to special‚Ä¶ most likely‚Ä¶

text:
Jensen Huang, CEO of NVIDIA, which produces the AI chips that are powering 80% of companies building AI, says coding is no longer something we need to learn. Is he right?

Well, the answer is always more complicated than it seems. 

Here's my answer: he's both right and wrong.

He's right in that we don't need to teach children Python or Java syntax as much as we needed to in the past. We can have AI-powered coding assistants correct issues, even code small programs just by talking to them in natural language (like we speak to each other).

But he is wrong if he was talking about teaching children computer science. 

Computer science and AI are a way of problem solving. 

Just like we didn't stop studying math when the calculator was invented, or will stop enjoying how to write poetry now that ChatGPT can write poems, we shouldn't stop learning how we can make computers think and solve grand challenges just because we have AI assistants. 

Huang is encouraging everyone to learn creative problem solving and I assert we should do it by all and any means available to us. Critical thinking, inter-disciplinary curriculums, problem solving, all require a set of tools and techniques, and computer science, statistics and AI are very much part of that toolkit as are personal AI assistants.

Ironically, the most effective method of learning may still be the centuries old Socratic approach, even as we race into tomorrow with AI.

What do you think about this?

-- The future awaits. Ayesha

#AI #education

Hier kommt RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) ins Spiel. I know - viele Fremdworte.

RAG erm√∂glicht es LLMs, direkt auf die internen Daten zuzugreifen, ohne sie vorher teuer trainieren zu m√ºssen. Einfach per txt, pdf, xls, etc.

Kein teures Training. Keine Komplexit√§t in der Softeare-Integration.

text:
Beyond the AI hype - there is an urgent call for action!

In the heart of the AI revolution, it's easy to get caught up in the bubble, believing that every company is on the brink of the next AI breakthrough.

The truth? While there's a surge of offerings and a constant buzz around AI, a significant gap exists between perception and reality. Many businesses are not as ready as they think, missing out on critical growth opportunities.

The rapid emergence of AI-fueled new market entrants is not just a warning sign for incumbents; it's a clear signal that the future belongs to those who embrace AI with curiosity, speed, a solid understanding, and well-defined goals. 

The risk? Companies that fail to adapt risk being left behind, or worse, displaced by those leveraging AI to drive exponential growth.

The era of AI is not a distant future; it's here, reshaping industries, redefining competition, and redrawing success maps. The time to move is now. Waiting on the sidelines is no longer an option.

Embrace AI, not as a buzzword, but as a strategic imperative to unlock your business's exponential growth potential.
